Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Edward Gold Papers TAM 570
8.5 Linear Feet in 8 record cartons and 2 flat boxes
1950s-2010 Edward Gold was a Democratic Party leader in New York City's Village Independent Democrats and a member of Community Board 2. This collection contains clippings, printed ephemera, some correspondence, reports, minutes, and photographs documenting Gold's political activities within the reform deocratic movement in New York City, community issues in Greenwich Village, and his college activities at Columbia University.
Materials are in English 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 10
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Diane Lebedeff, Executor of the Estate of Edward Gold, in 2011. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2011.019, 2011.022 and 2011.056.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist; materials are in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Historical/Biographical Note
Edward Gold (1926-2010) was born in the Bronx and earned a BA and MA in Journalism from Columbia University. He served as editor in chief of The Spectator and associate editor of the Columbia Yearbook. Later, Gold was a Democratic Party leader in New York City's Village Independent Democrats and a member of Community Board 2. Gold worked for 40 years as a writer and editor at Fairchild Publications, and after retiring continued to write opinion columns for The Villager. He was an early supporter of Ed Koch's political career, and headed the citywide Reform Democratic movement while serving as President of the Coalition of Democratic Voters. Following the sale of a federal post office on Christopher Street to a private developer, Gold oversaw the distribution of $1.6 million to the community.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Edward Gold Papers; TAM 570; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Scope and Contents
The collection contains clippings (including two oversize scrapbooks), printed ephemera, some correspondence (including a signed letter from Eleanor Roosevelt; a few letters to and from Ed Koch), reports, minutes, and photographs. In addition to documenting Gold's political activities within the reform deocratic movement in New York City and community issues in Greenwich Village, there are also biographical materials that include coverage of his youth and college activities at Columbia University.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Many materials are loose in boxes, and some materials are fragile.
Conditions Governing Use
Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by Edward Gold were transferred to New York University in 2011 by Diane Lebedeff. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu.
